repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Riga District Heating
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Riga District Heating Rehabilitation
            Project (RDHP) aimed to increase energy efficiency, and
            improve service levels of the heating system, through a
            Bank, and Swedish Loans to the Rigas Siltums Company, with
            the guarantee of the Republic of Latvia. However, the
            Ministry of Finance, subsequent to negotiations, questioned
            the condition in the Guarantee Agreement that required the
            Guarantor to cause the Energy Regulatory Board, to adjust
            heat tariffs on a regular basis, in order to allow the
            Borrower to recover appropriate costs, and remain
            competitive with other heating alternatives. Key concern was
            the uncertainty of disconnections from the District Heating
            (DH) system, in light of changes in the Energy Law, and
            removal of restrictions to install alternative heating
            systems, as well as concerns about the collateral to be
            provided by Rigas Siltums to back up the guarantee, and
            uncertainty over tariffs, and prices of alternative fuels.
            Given these risks, the Ministry of Finance could not issue a
            state guarantee, and, did not include the Project in the
            guarantee limit of the State Budget Law for 2001, nor for
            2002. Although the Bank is continuing specific energy market
            liberalization, and related gas and DH regulatory issues
            under a structural adjustment operation, the loans for RDHP
            have been withdrawn at the request of the Guarantor.

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Riga District Heating
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Riga District Heating (DH)
            Rehabilitation Project will optimize the operational
            performance of the DH system, increase the efficiency of
            heat supply, and improve reliability of service delivery.
            Energy conservation will be enhanced, and environmental
            conditions will improve, through transmission, and
            distribution of network rehabilitation, substation
            modernization, and new technologies. Pricing policies, and
            commercial practices will allow the competitive development
            of Rigas Siltums, to achieve eventual privatization. The two
            main components will: 1) supply, and install automated
            consumer substations to allow the introduction of variable
            flow, thus facilitate the dispatching of heat load from the
            current, underutilized plant, and in turn facilitate energy
            savings for consumers. Pipe sections will be replaced as
            needed to abate leaks, while construction of a pipeline
            interconnection, and installation of pumping stations will
            facilitate the right, and left bank networks heat demand; 2)
            include institutional support through consulting services in
            procurement, project financial reporting, and disbursement.
            In addition consulting services will be provided to assist
            in the evaluation for an applicable two-tier heat tariff,
            emphasizing its suitability through public awareness
            campaigns. Advisory services will improve municipal social
            assistance programs, and an evaluation of ownership options
            will be developed.

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Riga District Heating
            Rehabilitation Project : environmental impact review

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            reviews adverse environmental effects as a result of the
            Riga District Heating Rehabilitation Project implementation.
            Average air emissions are examined in different district
            heating plants, and the EA reports these emissions are
            remarkably low - same or lower levels - than nitrogen oxides
            emissions from modern plants. It is expected that heating
            plants do not cause significant odor, or dust problems,
            since natural gas, or heavy fuel oils are to be used.
            Neither does noise disturbances seem to be of great concern.
            However, air quality may be potentially harmful. In
            accordance with Latvian laws, all plants have to apply for
            operational permits, and comply with regional environmental
            protection regulations, and are also liable for taxes
            regarding emissions. While its is difficult to establish
            emissions' costs on the environment, the report
            compares these with Swedish environmental taxes, and
            determines each situation after suggested conversion,
            considering the emission levels, be it from carbon dioxide,
            sulfur dioxide, or nitrogen oxides. Demolition should be
            performed to contain asbestos, preventing its release, by
            packing asbestos waste until disposed at an approved
            landfill. Boilers should be airtight, refractory, and
            covered with mineral wool, and, underground pipes should be insulated.
